https://prez.dev/description.@value: The form of a sample, i.e. the visible shape or configuration of a geological material. The listing includes both primary samples and derived specimens, that is primary sources (e.g. drillcore, hand specimen) and items resulting from preparation of those source materials for the purpose of research/analytical work (e.g. thin section, fine powder). Artefacts are also included, but in this vocabulary they specifically refer to man-made objects of cultural or historical interest such as a tool or decoration (i.e. items such as thin sections, mounts, etc. are not regarded as artefacts in this context). Descriptions were compiled trying to avoid reference to the material that comprises the specimen (e.g. rock, fossil) or the sampling method (e.g. drilling), although in practice it is not always possible to completely separate these concepts from the sample type (e.g. rotary sidewall core); in fact many of the concepts for sample type and sample materials are (incorrectly) used interchangeably.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A translucent section of geological material prepared for microscope analysis. The rock slice is almost always glued to a glass slide backing and may or may not be covered in a thin glass coverslip. Thick sections are more than 30 μm in thickness, normally 100 μm.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A translucent section of geological material prepared for microscope analysis. The rock slice is almost always glued to a glass slide backing and may or may not be covered in a thin glass coverslip. Thick sections are more than 30 μm in thickness, normally 100 μm.
A polished translucent section of geological material prepared for microscope analysis that is greater than 30 μm in thickness, normally 100 μm.
